Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In late 1775, the newly appointed 
General George Washington received a poem from one 
of colonial America’s most famous writers. Its verses praised 
the burgeoning revolution, invoking the goddess of their new nation
to aid the general’s righteous cause. But this ode to liberty wasn’t written
by some aloof, aristocratic admirer. Its author was a young Black woman
who’d been enslaved for over a decade. The young girl, who’d been renamed
Phillis Wheatley, had arrived in the colonies
on a slave ship in 1761. The ship landed in Boston, where Susanna and John Wheatley purchased
Phillis to work in their house. However, for reasons that remain unclear,
they also taught her to read and write. Over the following decade, Wheatley became well versed 
in poetry and religious texts, eventually beginning to produce
her own poems. The family published her work 
in a local newspaper, and in 1771, her elegy for renowned 
reverend George Whitefield captured the public’s imagination. The poem’s repetitive rhythms,
dramatic religious references, and soaring spiritual language depicted how Whitefield’s sermons
“inflame the soul and captivate the mind.” Wheatley ends with an arresting image
of life after death, trusting that divine forces
“will re-animate his dust.” This moving tribute found an audience
in both the US and England. And since the piece was published 
with a note identifying the author as an enslaved woman, many readers were as fascinated 
with the poet as they were with the poem. In 1773, Phillis traveled to London, where her collection of “Poems 
on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral” became the first book of poetry published
by an African-American woman. It was filled with profound meditations
on life, death, and religion, as well as Biblical 
and classical references. In “A Hymn to Humanity,” Wheatley linked 
these themes to her own creative growth, portraying herself as a muse 
smiled upon by heavenly bodies. Unsurprisingly, Wheatley had her critics. Many white Americans believed 
Black people were incapable of producing intellectual 
and creative work. Thomas Jefferson wrote that her writing
didn't even deserve to be called poetry, and others dismissed her as a poor
imitation of another well-known poet. But many readers of the time were
enamored with Wheatley's work, including prominent European
writers and politicians. Many modern readers, however, might expect her work to cover
a different topic: slavery. Wheatley rarely wrote directly about her
experiences as an enslaved person. And her poem addressing the topic 
has been criticized for suggesting she was grateful 
that enslavement led her to Christianity. But it’s incredibly unlikely Wheatley 
would have been able to publicly condemn slavery without serious consequences. And many readers have found a more nuanced
critique hidden within her work. For example, Wheatley was a vocal
supporter of American independence, writing that her “love of freedom” 
came from early experiences of being kidnapped into slavery 
and separated from her parents. When disparaging England’s 
imperial control, she evokes imagery of an “iron chain.” And by comparing her lack of freedom
to America’s lack of independence, Wheatley subtly laments
her own circumstances. Thankfully, Wheatley secured her freedom
after returning from London. The reasons for her emancipation
aren't entirely clear, as there’s no evidence of the Wheatleys
freeing other enslaved people. However, since Phillis could have
remained free in London, some believe she bargained to make
emancipation a condition of her return. It’s difficult to know exactly 
what happened, both here and throughout the rest 
of Wheatley’s life. Her proposal for a second book
was never published. In 1778, she married a free 
Black man named John Peters. The two are believed to have had
three children, all of whom died in infancy. Their last child is thought to have died
around the same time as Wheatley, and the two were buried together
in an unmarked grave. While some of Wheatley’s letters survived,
she never released an account of her life. So despite her tenure as perhaps 
the most famous African on the planet, Wheatley’s story has been lost 
to the ravages of history, like those of countless other 
enslaved peoples. But her poetry lives on today— celebrating creative growth
and offering spiritual sustenance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When did Phillis Wheatley arrive in Boston?
Options: A. 1753, B. 1761, C. 1773, D. 1775
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who received a poem from Phillis Wheatley in late 1775? Options: A. Thomas Jefferson, B. General George Washington, C. George Whitefield, D. John Peters Correct Option: None
Question 2: Where did Phillis Wheatley arrive in the colonies in 1761? Options: A. New York, B. Boston, C. Philadelphia, D. London Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the title of Phillis Wheatley's collection of poetry published in 1773? Options: A. "A Hymn to Humanity", B. "Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral", C. "The Goddess of Liberty", D. "Elegy for George Whitefield" Correct Option: None
Question 4: Who wrote that Phillis Wheatley's writing didn't deserve to be called poetry? Options: A. Thomas Jefferson, B. George Whitefield, C. General George Washington, D. John Peters Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was a common criticism of Phillis Wheatley's poem addressing slavery? Options: A. It was too radical, B. It was too subtle, C. It suggested she was grateful for enslavement leading her to Christianity, D. It didn't address the topic at all Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was Phillis Wheatley a vocal supporter of? Options: A. British imperialism, B. American independence, C. Slavery, D. The abolition of poetry Correct Option: None
Question 7: What imagery did Phillis Wheatley evoke when disparaging England's imperial control? Options: A. A broken chain, B. An iron chain, C. A crown, D. A flag Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why might Phillis Wheatley have been emancipated after returning from London? Options: A. The Wheatleys freed all their enslaved people, B. She bargained to make emancipation a condition of her return, C. She was no longer useful to the Wheatleys, D. The reason is unknown Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happened to Phillis Wheatley's proposal for a second book? Options: A. It was published to great acclaim, B. It was rejected by publishers, C. It was never published, D. It was lost in a fire Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the current state of Phillis Wheatley's grave? Options: A. It is a grand monument, B. It is a small headstone, C. It is an unmarked grave, D. It is unknown Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of content (Phillis Wheatley's arrival in the colonies) and options (although the correct option is not explicitly stated, option B "Boston" is the correct answer based on the transcript). The question intent is also similar, as both questions aim to assess the reader's understanding of Phillis Wheatley's biography. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

General George Washington received a poem from one 
of colonial America’s most famous writers. Its verses praised

who’d been enslaved for over a decade. The young girl, who’d been renamed
Phillis Wheatley, had arrived in the colonies
on a slave ship in 1761. The ship landed in Boston, where Susanna and John Wheatley purchased
Phillis to work in their house. However, for reasons that remain unclear,
they also taught her to read and write. Over the following decade, Wheatley became well versed 
in poetry and religious texts, eventually beginning to produce
her own poems. The family published her work 
in a local newspaper, and in 1771, her elegy for renowned 
reverend George Whitefield captured the public’s imagination. The poem’s repetitive rhythms,
dramatic religious references, and soaring spiritual language depicted how Whitefield’s sermons
“inflame the soul and captivate the mind.” Wheatley ends with an arresting image
of life after death, trusting that divine forces
“will re-animate his dust.” This moving tribute found an audience
in both the US and England. And since the piece was published 
with a note identifying the author as an enslaved woman, many readers were as fascinated 
with the poet as they were with the poem. In 1773, Phillis traveled to London, where her collection of “Poems 
on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral” became the first book of poetry published
by an African-American woman. It was filled with profound meditations
on life, death, and religion, as well as Biblical 
and classical references. In “A Hymn to Humanity,” Wheatley linked 
these themes to her own creative growth, portraying herself as a muse 
smiled upon by heavenly bodies. Unsurprisingly, Wheatley had her critics. Many white Americans believed 
Black people were incapable of producing intellectual 
and creative work. Thomas Jefferson wrote that her writing
didn't even deserve to be called poetry, and others dismissed her as a poor
imitation of another well-known poet. But many readers of the time were
enamored with Wheatley's work, including prominent European
writers and politicians. Many modern readers, however, might expect her work to cover
a different topic: slavery. Wheatley rarely wrote directly about her
experiences as an enslaved person. And her poem addressing the topic 
has been criticized for suggesting she was grateful 
that enslavement led her to Christianity. But it’s incredibly unlikely Wheatley 
would have been able to publicly condemn slavery without serious consequences. And many readers have found a more nuanced
critique hidden within her work. For example, Wheatley was a vocal
supporter of American independence, writing that her “love of freedom” 
came from early experiences of being kidnapped into slavery 
and separated from her parents. When disparaging England’s 
imperial control, she evokes imagery of an “iron chain.” And by comparing her lack of freedom
to America’s lack of independence, Wheatley subtly laments
her own circumstances. Thankfully, Wheatley secured her freedom
after returning from London. The reasons for her emancipation
aren't entirely clear, as there’s no evidence of the Wheatleys
freeing other enslaved people. However, since Phillis could have
remained free in London, some believe she bargained to make
emancipation a condition of her return. It’s difficult to know exactly 
what happened, both here and throughout the rest 
of Wheatley’s life. Her proposal for a second book
was never published. In 1778, she married a free 
Black man named John Peters. The two are believed to have had
three children, all of whom died in infancy. Their last child is thought to have died
around the same time as Wheatley, and the two were buried together
in an unmarked grave. While some of Wheatley’s letters survived,
she never released an account of her life. So despite her tenure as perhaps 
the most famous African on the planet, Wheatley’s story has been lost 
to the ravages of history, like those of countless other 
enslaved peoples. But her poetry lives on today— celebrating creative growth
and offering spiritual sustenance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following subjects were often featured in Phillis Wheatley’s poetry?
Options: A. Christianity/Biblical stories, B. Classical literature, C. Politics, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: Where did Phillis Wheatley arrive in the colonies in 1761? Options: A. New York, B. Boston, C. Philadelphia, D. London Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the title of Phillis Wheatley's collection of poetry published in 1773? Options: A. "A Hymn to Humanity", B. "Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral", C. "The Goddess of Liberty", D. "Elegy for George Whitefield" Correct Option: None
Question 4: Who wrote that Phillis Wheatley's writing didn't deserve to be called poetry? Options: A. Thomas Jefferson, B. George Whitefield, C. General George Washington, D. John Peters Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was a common criticism of Phillis Wheatley's poem addressing slavery? Options: A. It was too radical, B. It was too subtle, C. It suggested she was grateful for enslavement leading her to Christianity, D. It didn't address the topic at all Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was Phillis Wheatley a vocal supporter of? Options: A. British imperialism, B. American independence, C. Slavery, D. The abolition of poetry Correct Option: None
Question 7: What imagery did Phillis Wheatley evoke when disparaging England's imperial control? Options: A. A broken chain, B. An iron chain, C. A crown, D. A flag Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why might Phillis Wheatley have been emancipated after returning from London? Options: A. The Wheatleys freed all their enslaved people, B. She bargained to make emancipation a condition of her return, C. She was no longer useful to the Wheatleys, D. The reason is unknown Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happened to Phillis Wheatley's proposal for a second book? Options: A. It was published to great acclaim, B. It was rejected by publishers, C. It was never published, D. It was lost in a fire Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the current state of Phillis Wheatley's grave? Options: A. It is a grand monument, B. It is a small headstone, C. It is an unmarked grave, D. It is unknown Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can try to find the one that is closest in terms of subject matter.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the subjects often featured in Phillis Wheatley's poetry. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 3 mentions the title of Phillis Wheatley's collection of poetry, which is related to her poetry's content.

However, a closer match can be found in the options of Question 6, which mentions Phillis Wheatley's support for American independence, and the transcript mentions that her poetry linked themes of life, death, and religion to her own creative growth and included Biblical and classical references.

But the closest match is still not very similar. If I had to choose, I would say that Question 6 is the closest, but it's still not a good match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At the age of 21, Simone de Beauvoir 
became the youngest person to take the philosophy exams
at France’s most esteemed university. She passed with flying colors. But as soon as she mastered 
the rules of philosophy, she wanted to break them. She’d been schooled 
on Plato’s Theory of Forms, which dismissed the physical world 
as a flawed reflection of higher truths and unchanging ideals. But for de Beauvoir, 
earthly life was enthralling, sensual, and anything but static. Her desire to explore the physical world 
to its fullest would shape her life, and eventually, 
inspire a radical new philosophy. Endlessly debating with her romantic 
and intellectual partner Jean Paul Sartre, de Beauvoir explored free will, desire, 
rights and responsibilities, and the value of personal experience. In the years following WWII, these ideas would converge 
into the school of thought most closely associated with their work: 
existentialism. Where Judeo-Christian traditions 
taught that humans are born with preordained purpose, de Beauvoir and Sartre proposed 
a revolutionary alternative. They argued that humans are born free, and thrown into existence 
without a divine plan. As de Beauvoir acknowledged, this freedom 
is both a blessing and a burden. In "The Ethics of Ambiguity" she argued 
that our greatest ethical imperative is to create our own life’s meaning, while protecting the freedom 
of others to do the same. As de Beauvoir wrote, “A freedom which is interested only 
in denying freedom must be denied.” This philosophy challenged its students 
to navigate the ambiguities and conflicts our desires produce, 
both internally and externally. And as de Beauvoir sought to find 
her own purpose, she began to question: if everyone deserves 
to freely pursue meaning, why was she restricted by society’s ideals
of womanhood? Despite her prolific writing, 
teaching and activism, de Beauvoir struggled 
to be taken seriously by her male peers. She’d rejected her Catholic upbringing 
and marital expectations to study at university, and write memoirs,
fiction and philosophy. But the risks she was taking 
by embracing this lifestyle were lost on many 
of her male counterparts, who took these freedoms for granted. They had no intellectual interest 
in de Beauvoir’s work, which explored women’s inner lives, as well the author’s open relationship 
and bisexuality. To convey the importance 
of her perspective, de Beauvoir embarked 
on her most challenging book yet. Just as she’d created the foundations 
of existentialism, she’d now redefine the limits of gender. Published in 1949, "The Second Sex" 
argues that, like our life’s meaning, gender is not predestined. As de Beauvoir famously wrote, “one is not born, but rather becomes, 
woman.” And to “become” a woman, she argued, 
was to become the Other. De Beauvoir defined Othering 
as the process of labeling women as less than the men who’d 
historically defined, and been defined as, the ideal human subjects. As the Other, she argued that women 
were considered second to men, and therefore systematically restricted 
from pursuing freedom. "The Second Sex" became 
an essential feminist treatise, offering a detailed history 
of women’s oppression and a wealth of anecdotal testimony. "The Second Sex"’s combination 
of personal experience and philosophical intervention provided a new language 
to discuss feminist theory. Today, those conversations are still 
informed by de Beauvoir’s insistence that in the pursuit of equality, “there is no divorce between 
philosophy and life.” Of course, like any foundational work, the ideas in "The Second Sex" have been 
expanded upon since its publication. Many modern thinkers have explored 
additional ways people are Othered that de Beauvoir doesn’t acknowledge. These include racial 
and economic identities, as well as the broader spectrum of gender 
and sexual identities we understand today. De Beauvoir’s legacy 
is further complicated by accusations of sexual misconduct 
by two of her university students. In the face of these accusations, she had her teaching license revoked 
for abusing her position. In this aspect and others, 
de Beauvoir’s life remains controversial— and her work represents a contentious 
moment in the emergence of early feminism. She participated in those conversations 
for the rest of her life; writing fiction, philosophy, 
and memoirs until her death in 1986. Today, her work offers 
a philosophical language to be reimagined, revisited 
and rebelled against— a response this revolutionary thinker 
might have welcomed.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Simone De Beauvoir wanted to use philosophy to:
Options: A. Explore abstract concepts, B. Explore the meaning of everyday life, C. Support Plato’s theory of forms, D. Explore religion
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: At what age did Simone de Beauvoir become the youngest person to take the philosophy exams at France's most esteemed university? Options: A. 18, B. 21, C. 25, D. 30 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What philosophical theory did Simone de Beauvoir disagree with due to its dismissal of the physical world? Options: A. Existentialism, B. Plato's Theory of Forms, C. The Ethics of Ambiguity, D. Judeo-Christian traditions Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who was Simone de Beauvoir's romantic and intellectual partner? Options: A. Jean-Paul Sartre, B. Plato, C. Friedrich Nietzsche, D. Martin Heidegger Correct Option: None
Question 4: What school of thought is most closely associated with the work of Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre? Options: A. Existentialism, B. Phenomenology, C. Marxism, D. Feminism Correct Option: None
Question 5: According to Simone de Beauvoir, what is humanity's greatest ethical imperative? Options: A. To follow a divine plan, B. To create our own life's meaning while protecting the freedom of others, C. To deny freedom to others, D. To pursue wealth and power Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the title of Simone de Beauvoir's book that argues that gender is not predestined? Options: A. "The Ethics of Ambiguity", B. "The Second Sex", C. "The Feminine Mystique", D. "The Other" Correct Option: None
Question 7: According to Simone de Beauvoir, what is the process of labeling women as less than men called? Options: A. Othering, B. Objectification, C. Marginalization, D. Oppression Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the result of the accusations of sexual misconduct against Simone de Beauvoir? Options: A. She was awarded a teaching position, B. She had her teaching license revoked, C. She was ignored by the academic community, D. She was praised for her actions Correct Option: None
Question 9: In what year was Simone de Beauvoir's book "The Second Sex" published? Options: A. 1945, B. 1949, C. 1955, D. 1960 Correct Option: None
Question 10: In what year did Simone de Beauvoir pass away? Options: A. 1976, B. 1986, C. 1996, D. 2006 Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

Although the wording is not identical, Question 5 aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ, which is to explore Simone de Beauvoir's philosophical perspective. The correct option in Question 5, "To create our own life's meaning while protecting the freedom of others," reflects de Beauvoir's emphasis on exploring everyday life and creating one's own meaning, as mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

However, it's worth noting that there isn't a perfect match among the generated MCQs, as none of them directly ask about de Beauvoir's purpose in using philosophy. Nevertheless, Question 5 is the closest match in terms of content and intent.

According to Simone de Beauvoir, what is humanity's greatest ethical imperative?

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At the age of 21, Simone de Beauvoir 
became the youngest person to take the philosophy exams
at France’s most esteemed university. She passed with flying colors. But as soon as she mastered 
the rules of philosophy, she wanted to break them. She’d been schooled 
on Plato’s Theory of Forms, which dismissed the physical world 
as a flawed reflection of higher truths and unchanging ideals. But for de Beauvoir, 
earthly life was enthralling, sensual, and anything but static. Her desire to explore the physical world 
to its fullest would shape her life, and eventually, 
inspire a radical new philosophy. Endlessly debating with her romantic 
and intellectual partner Jean Paul Sartre, de Beauvoir explored free will, desire, 
rights and responsibilities, and the value of personal experience. In the years following WWII, these ideas would converge 
into the school of thought most closely associated with their work: 
existentialism. Where Judeo-Christian traditions 
taught that humans are born with preordained purpose, de Beauvoir and Sartre proposed 
a revolutionary alternative. They argued that humans are born free, and thrown into existence 
without a divine plan. As de Beauvoir acknowledged, this freedom 
is both a blessing and a burden. In "The Ethics of Ambiguity" she argued 
that our greatest ethical imperative is to create our own life’s meaning, while protecting the freedom 
of others to do the same. As de Beauvoir wrote, “A freedom which is interested only 
in denying freedom must be denied.” This philosophy challenged its students 
to navigate the ambiguities and conflicts our desires produce, 
both internally and externally. And as de Beauvoir sought to find 
her own purpose, she began to question: if everyone deserves 
to freely pursue meaning, why was she restricted by society’s ideals
of womanhood? Despite her prolific writing, 
teaching and activism, de Beauvoir struggled 
to be taken seriously by her male peers. She’d rejected her Catholic upbringing 
and marital expectations to study at university, and write memoirs,
fiction and philosophy. But the risks she was taking 
by embracing this lifestyle were lost on many 
of her male counterparts, who took these freedoms for granted. They had no intellectual interest 
in de Beauvoir’s work, which explored women’s inner lives, as well the author’s open relationship 
and bisexuality. To convey the importance 
of her perspective, de Beauvoir embarked 
on her most challenging book yet. Just as she’d created the foundations 
of existentialism, she’d now redefine the limits of gender. Published in 1949, "The Second Sex" 
argues that, like our life’s meaning, gender is not predestined. As de Beauvoir famously wrote, “one is not born, but rather becomes, 
woman.” And to “become” a woman, she argued, 
was to become the Other. De Beauvoir defined Othering 
as the process of labeling women as less than the men who’d 
historically defined, and been defined as, the ideal human subjects. As the Other, she argued that women 
were considered second to men, and therefore systematically restricted 
from pursuing freedom. "The Second Sex" became 
an essential feminist treatise, offering a detailed history 
of women’s oppression and a wealth of anecdotal testimony. "The Second Sex"’s combination 
of personal experience and philosophical intervention provided a new language 
to discuss feminist theory. Today, those conversations are still 
informed by de Beauvoir’s insistence that in the pursuit of equality, “there is no divorce between 
philosophy and life.” Of course, like any foundational work, the ideas in "The Second Sex" have been 
expanded upon since its publication. Many modern thinkers have explored 
additional ways people are Othered that de Beauvoir doesn’t acknowledge. These include racial 
and economic identities, as well as the broader spectrum of gender 
and sexual identities we understand today. De Beauvoir’s legacy 
is further complicated by accusations of sexual misconduct 
by two of her university students. In the face of these accusations, she had her teaching license revoked 
for abusing her position. In this aspect and others, 
de Beauvoir’s life remains controversial— and her work represents a contentious 
moment in the emergence of early feminism. She participated in those conversations 
for the rest of her life; writing fiction, philosophy, 
and memoirs until her death in 1986. Today, her work offers 
a philosophical language to be reimagined, revisited 
and rebelled against— a response this revolutionary thinker 
might have welcomed.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In The Second Sex, De Beauvoir argued that
Options: A. Gender roles are naturally occurring, B. Gender is socially constructed, and is the most oppressed social position, C. Gender is socially and culturally constructed, and is one of many ways in which people are oppressed
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: At what age did Simone de Beauvoir become the youngest person to take the philosophy exams at France's most esteemed university? Options: A. 18, B. 21, C. 25, D. 30 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What philosophical theory did Simone de Beauvoir disagree with due to its dismissal of the physical world? Options: A. Existentialism, B. Plato's Theory of Forms, C. The Ethics of Ambiguity, D. Judeo-Christian traditions Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who was Simone de Beauvoir's romantic and intellectual partner? Options: A. Jean-Paul Sartre, B. Plato, C. Friedrich Nietzsche, D. Martin Heidegger Correct Option: None
Question 4: What school of thought is most closely associated with the work of Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre? Options: A. Existentialism, B. Phenomenology, C. Marxism, D. Feminism Correct Option: None
Question 5: According to Simone de Beauvoir, what is humanity's greatest ethical imperative? Options: A. To follow a divine plan, B. To create our own life's meaning while protecting the freedom of others, C. To deny freedom to others, D. To pursue wealth and power Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the title of Simone de Beauvoir's book that argues that gender is not predestined? Options: A. "The Ethics of Ambiguity", B. "The Second Sex", C. "The Feminine Mystique", D. "The Other" Correct Option: None
Question 7: According to Simone de Beauvoir, what is the process of labeling women as less than men called? Options: A. Othering, B. Objectification, C. Marginalization, D. Oppression Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the result of the accusations of sexual misconduct against Simone de Beauvoir? Options: A. She was awarded a teaching position, B. She had her teaching license revoked, C. She was ignored by the academic community, D. She was praised for her actions Correct Option: None

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

However, this question does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it only asks for the title of the book and does not address the specific argument made by De Beauvoir. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At the age of 21, Simone de Beauvoir 
became the youngest person to take the philosophy exams
at France’s most esteemed university. She passed with flying colors. But as soon as she mastered 
the rules of philosophy, she wanted to break them. She’d been schooled 
on Plato’s Theory of Forms, which dismissed the physical world 
as a flawed reflection of higher truths and unchanging ideals. But for de Beauvoir, 
earthly life was enthralling, sensual, and anything but static. Her desire to explore the physical world 
to its fullest would shape her life, and eventually, 
inspire a radical new philosophy. Endlessly debating with her romantic 
and intellectual partner Jean Paul Sartre, de Beauvoir explored free will, desire, 
rights and responsibilities, and the value of personal experience. In the years following WWII, these ideas would converge 
into the school of thought most closely associated with their work: 
existentialism. Where Judeo-Christian traditions 
taught that humans are born with preordained purpose, de Beauvoir and Sartre proposed 
a revolutionary alternative. They argued that humans are born free, and thrown into existence 
without a divine plan. As de Beauvoir acknowledged, this freedom 
is both a blessing and a burden. In "The Ethics of Ambiguity" she argued 
that our greatest ethical imperative is to create our own life’s meaning, while protecting the freedom 
of others to do the same. As de Beauvoir wrote, “A freedom which is interested only 
in denying freedom must be denied.” This philosophy challenged its students 
to navigate the ambiguities and conflicts our desires produce, 
both internally and externally. And as de Beauvoir sought to find 
her own purpose, she began to question: if everyone deserves 
to freely pursue meaning, why was she restricted by society’s ideals
of womanhood? Despite her prolific writing, 
teaching and activism, de Beauvoir struggled 
to be taken seriously by her male peers. She’d rejected her Catholic upbringing 
and marital expectations to study at university, and write memoirs,
fiction and philosophy. But the risks she was taking 
by embracing this lifestyle were lost on many 
of her male counterparts, who took these freedoms for granted. They had no intellectual interest 
in de Beauvoir’s work, which explored women’s inner lives, as well the author’s open relationship 
and bisexuality. To convey the importance 
of her perspective, de Beauvoir embarked 
on her most challenging book yet. Just as she’d created the foundations 
of existentialism, she’d now redefine the limits of gender. Published in 1949, "The Second Sex" 
argues that, like our life’s meaning, gender is not predestined. As de Beauvoir famously wrote, “one is not born, but rather becomes, 
woman.” And to “become” a woman, she argued, 
was to become the Other. De Beauvoir defined Othering 
as the process of labeling women as less than the men who’d 
historically defined, and been defined as, the ideal human subjects. As the Other, she argued that women 
were considered second to men, and therefore systematically restricted 
from pursuing freedom. "The Second Sex" became 
an essential feminist treatise, offering a detailed history 
of women’s oppression and a wealth of anecdotal testimony. "The Second Sex"’s combination 
of personal experience and philosophical intervention provided a new language 
to discuss feminist theory. Today, those conversations are still 
informed by de Beauvoir’s insistence that in the pursuit of equality, “there is no divorce between 
philosophy and life.” Of course, like any foundational work, the ideas in "The Second Sex" have been 
expanded upon since its publication. Many modern thinkers have explored 
additional ways people are Othered that de Beauvoir doesn’t acknowledge. These include racial 
and economic identities, as well as the broader spectrum of gender 
and sexual identities we understand today. De Beauvoir’s legacy 
is further complicated by accusations of sexual misconduct 
by two of her university students. In the face of these accusations, she had her teaching license revoked 
for abusing her position. In this aspect and others, 
de Beauvoir’s life remains controversial— and her work represents a contentious 
moment in the emergence of early feminism. She participated in those conversations 
for the rest of her life; writing fiction, philosophy, 
and memoirs until her death in 1986. Today, her work offers 
a philosophical language to be reimagined, revisited 
and rebelled against— a response this revolutionary thinker 
might have welcomed.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To make her arguments in The Second Sex, De Beauvoir
Options: A. Drew on women’s lived experience, B. Wrote about the history of women’s oppression, C. Created a theory of how gender works in everyday life, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the German town of Nördlingen in 1593, an innkeeper named Maria Höll found 
herself accused of witchcraft. She was arrested for questioning, 
and denied the charges. She continued to insist she wasn’t a witch
through 62 rounds of torture before her accusers finally released her. Rebekka Lemp, accused a few years earlier
in the same town, faced a worse fate. She wrote to her husband from jail worrying that she would 
confess under torture, even though she was innocent. After giving a false confession, she was burned at the stake 
in front of her family. Höll and Lemp were both victims of the 
witch hunts that occurred in Europe and the American 
colonies from the late 15th century 
until the early 18th century. These witch hunts were not a unified 
initiative by a single authority, but rather a phenomenon that occurred 
sporadically and followed a similar pattern each time. The term “witch” has taken 
on many meanings, but in these hunts, a witch was someone 
who allegedly gained magical powers by obeying Satan rather than God. This definition of witchcraft spread 
through churches in Western Europe starting at the end of the 15th century. It really gained traction after the pope 
gave a friar and professor of theology named Heinrich Kraemer permission to conduct inquisitions in 
search of witches in 1485. His first, in the town of Innsbruck, didn’t gain much traction with the local
authorities, who disapproved of his harsh questioning
of respectable citizens and shut down his trials. Undeterred, he wrote a book called the 
"Malleus Maleficarum," or "Hammer of Witches." The text argued for the existence of 
witches and suggested ruthless tactics for hunting
and prosecuting them. He singled out women as easier targets for
the devil’s influence, though men could also be witches. Kraemer’s book spurred others to write 
their own books and give sermons on the 
dangers of witchcraft. According to these texts, witches practiced rituals including 
kissing the Devil’s anus and poisoning or bewitching targets the 
devil singled out for harm. Though there was no evidence to support
any of these claims, belief in witches became widespread. A witch hunt often began 
with a misfortune: a failed harvest, a sick cow, 
or a stillborn child. Community members blamed witchcraft, 
and accused each other of being witches. Many of the accused were people on 
the fringes of society: the elderly, the poor, or social outcasts, but any member of the community
could be targeted, even occasionally children. While religious authorities encouraged 
witch hunts, local secular governments usually carried 
out the detainment and punishment of accused witches. Those suspected of witchcraft were 
questioned and often tortured— and under torture, thousands of innocent 
people confessed to witchcraft and implicated others in turn. Because these witch hunts occurred 
sporadically over centuries and continents the specifics varied considerably. Punishments for convicted witches ranged 
from small fines to burning at the stake. The hunt in which Höll and Lemp were 
accused dragged on for nine years, while others lasted just months. They could have anywhere from a few to a 
few hundred victims. The motivations of the witch hunters 
probably varied as well, but it seems likely that many weren’t 
consciously looking for scapegoats— instead, they sincerely believed 
in witchcraft, and thought they were doing good by 
rooting it out in their communities. Institutions of power enabled real harm to
be done on the basis of these beliefs. But there were dissenters all along– jurists, scholars, and physicians 
countered books like Kraemer’s "Hammer of Witches" with texts objecting to the 
cruelty of the hunts, the use of forced confessions, 
and the lack of evidence of witchcraft. From the late 17th through the mid-18th 
century, their arguments gained force with the rise
of stronger central governments and legal norms like due process. Witch hunting slowly declined until it 
disappeared altogether. Both the onset and demise of these 
atrocities came gradually, out of seemingly ordinary circumstances. The potential for similar situations, in which authorities use their powers to
mobilize society against a false threat, still exists today— but so does the capacity of reasoned 
dissent to combat those false beliefs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Witch Hunts in Europe finally declined because of
Options: A. stronger and more authoritative governments, B. ideas and books contradicting the belief in witches, C. objections to forced confessions, D. improved legal protections for the accused, E. all of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In which year did Maria Höll, an innkeeper from Nördlingen, face accusations of witchcraft? Options: A. 1485, B. 1593, C. 1650, D. 1700 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the outcome for Rebekka Lemp, who was accused of witchcraft in the same town as Maria Höll? Options: A. She was released after 62 rounds of torture., B. She was burned at the stake after giving a false confession., C. She was fined and released., D. She escaped from jail. Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who wrote the book "Malleus Maleficarum," also known as "Hammer of Witches"? Options: A. Maria Höll, B. Rebekka Lemp, C. Heinrich Kraemer, D. The Pope Correct Option: None
Question 4: According to the text, what was the definition of a witch during the witch hunts in Europe and the American colonies? Options: A. Someone who allegedly gained magical powers by obeying God., B. Someone who allegedly gained magical powers by obeying Satan., C. Someone who practiced rituals and had supernatural abilities., D. Someone who was a social outcast. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was often the trigger for a witch hunt to begin? Options: A. A successful harvest, B. A misfortune, such as a failed harvest or a sick cow, C. A sermon by a priest, D. A book about witchcraft Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who typically carried out the detainment and punishment of accused witches? Options: A. Religious authorities, B. Local secular governments, C. The community members, D. The accused witches' families Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was a common outcome for those suspected of witchcraft during the witch hunts? Options: A. They were released without punishment., B. They were fined and released., C. They were questioned and often tortured, leading to false confessions., D. They were immediately burned at the stake. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the approximate time period during which the witch hunts occurred in Europe and the American colonies? Options: A. Late 15th century to early 16th century, B. Late 15th century to early 18th century, C. Late 16th century to early 17th century, D. Late 17th century to early 18th century Correct Option: None
Question 9: Who were some of the individuals who countered the witch hunts with texts objecting to the cruelty and lack of evidence? Options: A. Jurists, scholars, and physicians, B. Priests, friars, and theologians, C. Community members and social outcasts, D. Accused witches and their families Correct Option: None
Question 10: What contributed to the decline of witch hunting in the late 17th and mid-18th centuries? Options: A. The rise of stronger central governments and legal norms like due process, B. The increase in witchcraft accusations and trials, C. The decrease in the number of witches, D. The lack of evidence of witchcraft Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10. 

Although the options in Question 10 do not exactly match the options in the ground truth MCQ, the question content and intent are similar. Both questions discuss the decline of witch hunting, and the correct option in Question 10 (A. The rise of stronger central governments and legal norms like due process) is similar to option E in the ground truth MCQ (all of the above), which includes "stronger and more authoritative governments" as one of the reasons for the decline of witch hunting.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:

herself accused of witchcraft. She was arrested for questioning, 
and denied the charges. She continued to insist she wasn’t a witch
through 62 rounds of torture before her accusers finally released her. Rebekka Lemp, accused a few years earlier
in the same town, faced a worse fate. She wrote to her husband from jail worrying that she would 
confess under torture, even though she was innocent. After giving a false confession, she was burned at the stake 
in front of her family. Höll and Lemp were both victims of the 
witch hunts that occurred in Europe and the American 
colonies from the late 15th century 
until the early 18th century. These witch hunts were not a unified 
initiative by a single authority, but rather a phenomenon that occurred 
sporadically and followed a similar pattern each time. The term “witch” has taken 
on many meanings, but in these hunts, a witch was someone 
who allegedly gained magical powers by obeying Satan rather than God. This definition of witchcraft spread 
through churches in Western Europe starting at the end of the 15th century. It really gained traction after the pope 
gave a friar and professor of theology named Heinrich Kraemer permission to conduct inquisitions in 
search of witches in 1485. His first, in the town of Innsbruck, didn’t gain much traction with the local
authorities, who disapproved of his harsh questioning
of respectable citizens and shut down his trials. Undeterred, he wrote a book called the 
"Malleus Maleficarum," or "Hammer of Witches." The text argued for the existence of 
witches and suggested ruthless tactics for hunting
and prosecuting them. He singled out women as easier targets for
the devil’s influence, though men could also be witches. Kraemer’s book spurred others to write 
their own books and give sermons on the 
dangers of witchcraft. According to these texts, witches practiced rituals including 
kissing the Devil’s anus and poisoning or bewitching targets the 
devil singled out for harm. Though there was no evidence to support
any of these claims, belief in witches became widespread. A witch hunt often began 
with a misfortune: a failed harvest, a sick cow, 
or a stillborn child. Community members blamed witchcraft, 
and accused each other of being witches. Many of the accused were people on 
the fringes of society: the elderly, the poor, or social outcasts, but any member of the community
could be targeted, even occasionally children. While religious authorities encouraged 
witch hunts, local secular governments usually carried 
out the detainment and punishment of accused witches. Those suspected of witchcraft were 
questioned and often tortured— and under torture, thousands of innocent 
people confessed to witchcraft and implicated others in turn. Because these witch hunts occurred 
sporadically over centuries and continents the specifics varied considerably. Punishments for convicted witches ranged 
from small fines to burning at the stake. The hunt in which Höll and Lemp were 
accused dragged on for nine years, while others lasted just months. They could have anywhere from a few to a 
few hundred victims. The motivations of the witch hunters 
probably varied as well, but it seems likely that many weren’t 
consciously looking for scapegoats— instead, they sincerely believed 
in witchcraft, and thought they were doing good by 
rooting it out in their communities. Institutions of power enabled real harm to
be done on the basis of these beliefs. But there were dissenters all along– jurists, scholars, and physicians 
countered books like Kraemer’s "Hammer of Witches" with texts objecting to the 
cruelty of the hunts, the use of forced confessions, 
and the lack of evidence of witchcraft. From the late 17th through the mid-18th 
century, their arguments gained force with the rise
of stronger central governments and legal norms like due process. Witch hunting slowly declined until it 
disappeared altogether. Both the onset and demise of these 
atrocities came gradually, out of seemingly ordinary circumstances. The potential for similar situations, in which authorities use their powers to
mobilize society against a false threat, still exists today— but so does the capacity of reasoned 
dissent to combat those false beliefs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Most of the “witches” targeted in the Witch Hunts were defined as people
Options: A. for whom connections to nature provided supernatural skills, B. who tapped into their inner power to cast spells, C. who learned magic by studying books about sorcery, D. to whom Satan had given magical powers
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the German town of Nördlingen in 1593, an innkeeper named Maria Höll found 
herself accused of witchcraft. She was arrested for questioning, 
and denied the charges. She continued to insist she wasn’t a witch
through 62 rounds of torture before her accusers finally released her. Rebekka Lemp, accused a few years earlier
in the same town, faced a worse fate. She wrote to her husband from jail worrying that she would 
confess under torture, even though she was innocent. After giving a false confession, she was burned at the stake 
in front of her family. Höll and Lemp were both victims of the 
witch hunts that occurred in Europe and the American 
colonies from the late 15th century 
until the early 18th century. These witch hunts were not a unified 
initiative by a single authority, but rather a phenomenon that occurred 
sporadically and followed a similar pattern each time. The term “witch” has taken 
on many meanings, but in these hunts, a witch was someone 
who allegedly gained magical powers by obeying Satan rather than God. This definition of witchcraft spread 
through churches in Western Europe starting at the end of the 15th century. It really gained traction after the pope 
gave a friar and professor of theology named Heinrich Kraemer permission to conduct inquisitions in 
search of witches in 1485. His first, in the town of Innsbruck, didn’t gain much traction with the local
authorities, who disapproved of his harsh questioning
of respectable citizens and shut down his trials. Undeterred, he wrote a book called the 
"Malleus Maleficarum," or "Hammer of Witches." The text argued for the existence of 
witches and suggested ruthless tactics for hunting
and prosecuting them. He singled out women as easier targets for
the devil’s influence, though men could also be witches. Kraemer’s book spurred others to write 
their own books and give sermons on the 
dangers of witchcraft. According to these texts, witches practiced rituals including 
kissing the Devil’s anus and poisoning or bewitching targets the 
devil singled out for harm. Though there was no evidence to support
any of these claims, belief in witches became widespread. A witch hunt often began 
with a misfortune: a failed harvest, a sick cow, 
or a stillborn child. Community members blamed witchcraft, 
and accused each other of being witches. Many of the accused were people on 
the fringes of society: the elderly, the poor, or social outcasts, but any member of the community
could be targeted, even occasionally children. While religious authorities encouraged 
witch hunts, local secular governments usually carried 
out the detainment and punishment of accused witches. Those suspected of witchcraft were 
questioned and often tortured— and under torture, thousands of innocent 
people confessed to witchcraft and implicated others in turn. Because these witch hunts occurred 
sporadically over centuries and continents the specifics varied considerably. Punishments for convicted witches ranged 
from small fines to burning at the stake. The hunt in which Höll and Lemp were 
accused dragged on for nine years, while others lasted just months. They could have anywhere from a few to a 
few hundred victims. The motivations of the witch hunters 
probably varied as well, but it seems likely that many weren’t 
consciously looking for scapegoats— instead, they sincerely believed 
in witchcraft, and thought they were doing good by 
rooting it out in their communities. Institutions of power enabled real harm to
be done on the basis of these beliefs. But there were dissenters all along– jurists, scholars, and physicians 
countered books like Kraemer’s "Hammer of Witches" with texts objecting to the 
cruelty of the hunts, the use of forced confessions, 
and the lack of evidence of witchcraft. From the late 17th through the mid-18th 
century, their arguments gained force with the rise
of stronger central governments and legal norms like due process. Witch hunting slowly declined until it 
disappeared altogether. Both the onset and demise of these 
atrocities came gradually, out of seemingly ordinary circumstances. The potential for similar situations, in which authorities use their powers to
mobilize society against a false threat, still exists today— but so does the capacity of reasoned 
dissent to combat those false beliefs.

Options: A. A Discovery of Witches, B. The Hammer of Witches, C. Malice of Magic, D. Malicious Women
Correct Option: B

and denied the charges. She continued to insist she wasn’t a witch
through 62 rounds of torture before her accusers finally released her. Rebekka Lemp, accused a few years earlier

Options: A. the use of harsh questioning and torture, B. careful investigation and collection of evidence, C. informants who had actually witnessed witchcraft, D. victims who realistically named witches as the cause of their suffering3

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Three and a half thousand years ago in Egypt, a noble pharaoh was the victim 
of a violent attack. But the attack was not physical. This royal had been dead for 20 years. The attack was historical, an act of damnatio memoriae,
the damnation of memory. Somebody smashed the pharaoh's statues, took a chisel and attempted to erase 
the pharaoh's name and image from history. Who was this pharaoh,
and what was behind the attack? Here's the key: the pharaoh Hatshepsut was a woman. In the normal course of things,
she should never have been pharaoh. Although it was legal 
for a woman to be a monarch, it disturbed some essential Egyptian beliefs. Firstly, the pharaoh was known
as the living embodiment of the male god Horus. Secondly, disturbance to the tradition
of rule by men was a serious challenge to Maat, a word for "truth," 
expressing a belief in order and justice, vital to the Egyptians. Hatshepsut had perhaps tried to adapt to this belief in the link between 
order and patriarchy through her titles. She took the name Maatkare, and sometimes referred to herself as Hatshepsu, 
with a masculine word ending. But apparently, these efforts 
didn't convince everyone, and perhaps someone 
erased Hatshepsut's image so that the world would forget 
the disturbance to Maat, and Egypt could be balanced again. Hatshepsut, moreover, 
was not the legitimate heir to the thrown, but a regent, 
a kind of stand-in co-monarch. The Egyptian kingship traditionally 
passed from father to son. It passed from Thutmose I 
to his son Thutmose II, Hatshepsut's husband. It should have passed from Thutmose II 
directly to his son Thutmose III, but Thutmose III was a little boy 
when his father died. Hatshepsut, the dead pharaoh's chief wife and widow, stepped in to help 
as her stepson's regent but ended up ruling beside him 
as a fully fledged pharaoh. Perhaps Thutmose III was angry about this. Perhaps he was the one 
who erased her images. It's also possible that someone wanted 
to dishonor Hatshepsut because she was a bad pharaoh. But the evidence suggests 
she was actually pretty good. She competently fulfilled 
the traditional roles of the office. She was a great builder. Her mortuary temple, Djeser-Djeseru, was an architectural phenomenon 
at the time and is still admired today. She enhanced the economy of Egypt, conducting a very successful trade mission
to the distant land of Punt. She had strong religious connections. She even claimed to be the daughter 
of the state god, Amun. And she had a successful military career,
with a Nubian campaign, and claims she fought alongside 
her soldiers in battle. Of course, we have to be careful
when we assess the success of Hatshepsut's career, since most of the evidence 
was written by Hatshepsut herself. She tells her own story 
in pictures and writing on the walls of her mortuary temple and the red chapel she built for Amun. So who committed the crimes 
against Hatshepsut's memory? The most popular suspect is 
her stepson, nephew and co-ruler, Thutmose III. Did he do it out of anger 
because she stole his throne? This is unlikely since 
the damage wasn't done until 20 years after Hatshepsut died. That's a long time to hang onto anger 
and then act in a rage. Maybe Thutmose III did it 
to make his own reign look stronger. But it is most likely that 
he or someone else erased the images so that people would forget 
that a woman ever sat on Egypt's throne. This gender anomaly was simply 
too much of a threat to Maat and had to be obliterated from history. Happily, the ancient censors 
were not quite thorough enough. Enough evidence survived for us 
to piece together what happened, so the story of this unique powerful woman
can now be told.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is maat?
Options: A. Egyptian food, B. Truth and justice, C. An Egyptian pharaoh, D. Have a male pharaoh
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the nature of the attack on the Egyptian pharaoh 3,500 years ago? Options: A. Physical attack, B. Historical attack, an act of damnatio memoriae, C. Economic attack, D. Military attack Correct Option: None

Question 3: What was the significance of the pharaoh being known as the living embodiment of the male god Horus? Options: A. It emphasized the importance of female pharaohs, B. It reinforced the tradition of rule by men, C. It established the pharaoh as a divine being, D. It created a separation between the pharaoh and the people Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the name of the concept that represented truth, order, and justice in ancient Egyptian society? Options: A. Maat, B. Ka, C. Ba, D. Anubis Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why did Hatshepsut take the name Maatkare and sometimes refer to herself as Hatshepsu? Options: A. To assert her dominance over her stepson, B. To adapt to the Egyptian belief in the link between order and patriarchy, C. To establish herself as a divine being, D. To separate herself from her husband's legacy Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who was the legitimate heir to the throne after Thutmose II's death? Options: A. Hatshepsut, B. Thutmose III, C. Thutmose I, D. Ahmose I Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the name of Hatshepsut's successful trade mission? Options: A. The expedition to Nubia, B. The campaign to Punt, C. The journey to Mesopotamia, D. The voyage to Greece Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the name of the architectural phenomenon built by Hatshepsut? Options: A. The Great Pyramid of Giza, B. The Temple of Karnak, C. Djeser-Djeseru, D. The Red Chapel Correct Option: None
Question 9: Who is the most popular suspect behind the erasure of Hatshepsut's images? Options: A. Thutmose I, B. Thutmose II, C. Thutmose III, D. Ahmose I Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why did the ancient Egyptians likely erase Hatshepsut's images? Options: A. Because she was a bad pharaoh, B. Because she stole the throne from Thutmose III, C. Because her reign was a threat to the tradition of male rule and Maat, D. Because she was a foreigner Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: What was the name of the concept that represented truth, order, and justice in ancient Egyptian society? Options: A. Maat, B. Ka, C. Ba, D. Anubis.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the concept of "maat" and its meaning in ancient Egyptian society. The correct option in both questions is "Maat" or a definition that matches the concept of Maat.

and what was behind the attack? Here's the key: the pharaoh Hatshepsut was a woman. In the normal course of things,
she should never have been pharaoh. Although it was legal 
for a woman to be a monarch, it disturbed some essential Egyptian beliefs. Firstly, the pharaoh was known
as the living embodiment of the male god Horus. Secondly, disturbance to the tradition
of rule by men was a serious challenge to Maat, a word for "truth," 
expressing a belief in order and justice, vital to the Egyptians. Hatshepsut had perhaps tried to adapt to this belief in the link between 
order and patriarchy through her titles. She took the name Maatkare, and sometimes referred to herself as Hatshepsu, 
with a masculine word ending. But apparently, these efforts 
didn't convince everyone, and perhaps someone 
erased Hatshepsut's image so that the world would forget 
the disturbance to Maat, and Egypt could be balanced again. Hatshepsut, moreover, 
was not the legitimate heir to the thrown, but a regent, 
a kind of stand-in co-monarch. The Egyptian kingship traditionally 
passed from father to son. It passed from Thutmose I 
to his son Thutmose II, Hatshepsut's husband. It should have passed from Thutmose II 
directly to his son Thutmose III, but Thutmose III was a little boy 
when his father died. Hatshepsut, the dead pharaoh's chief wife and widow, stepped in to help 
as her stepson's regent but ended up ruling beside him 
as a fully fledged pharaoh. Perhaps Thutmose III was angry about this. Perhaps he was the one 
who erased her images. It's also possible that someone wanted 
to dishonor Hatshepsut because she was a bad pharaoh. But the evidence suggests 
she was actually pretty good. She competently fulfilled 
the traditional roles of the office. She was a great builder. Her mortuary temple, Djeser-Djeseru, was an architectural phenomenon 
at the time and is still admired today. She enhanced the economy of Egypt, conducting a very successful trade mission
to the distant land of Punt. She had strong religious connections. She even claimed to be the daughter 
of the state god, Amun. And she had a successful military career,
with a Nubian campaign, and claims she fought alongside 
her soldiers in battle. Of course, we have to be careful
when we assess the success of Hatshepsut's career, since most of the evidence 
was written by Hatshepsut herself. She tells her own story 
in pictures and writing on the walls of her mortuary temple and the red chapel she built for Amun. So who committed the crimes 
against Hatshepsut's memory? The most popular suspect is 
her stepson, nephew and co-ruler, Thutmose III. Did he do it out of anger 
because she stole his throne? This is unlikely since 
the damage wasn't done until 20 years after Hatshepsut died. That's a long time to hang onto anger 
and then act in a rage. Maybe Thutmose III did it 
to make his own reign look stronger. But it is most likely that 
he or someone else erased the images so that people would forget 
that a woman ever sat on Egypt's throne. This gender anomaly was simply 
too much of a threat to Maat and had to be obliterated from history. Happily, the ancient censors 
were not quite thorough enough. Enough evidence survived for us 
to piece together what happened, so the story of this unique powerful woman
can now be told.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why was it unusual that Hatshepsut became pharaoh?
Options: A. She was a woman, B. She was not the heir to the throne, C. There was already a pharaoh on the throne, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Question 3: What was the significance of the pharaoh being known as the living embodiment of the male god Horus? Options: A. It emphasized the importance of female pharaohs, B. It reinforced the tradition of rule by men, C. It established the pharaoh as a divine being, D. It created a separation between the pharaoh and the people Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the name of the concept that represented truth, order, and justice in ancient Egyptian society? Options: A. Maat, B. Ka, C. Ba, D. Anubis Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why did Hatshepsut take the name Maatkare and sometimes refer to herself as Hatshepsu? Options: A. To assert her dominance over her stepson, B. To adapt to the Egyptian belief in the link between order and patriarchy, C. To establish herself as a divine being, D. To separate herself from her husband's legacy Correct Option: None
Question 6: Who was the legitimate heir to the throne after Thutmose II's death? Options: A. Hatshepsut, B. Thutmose III, C. Thutmose I, D. Ahmose I Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the name of Hatshepsut's successful trade mission? Options: A. The expedition to Nubia, B. The campaign to Punt, C. The journey to Mesopotamia, D. The voyage to Greece Correct Option: None

Question 10: Why did the ancient Egyptians likely erase Hatshepsut's images? Options: A. Because she was a bad pharaoh, B. Because she stole the throne from Thutmose III, C. Because her reign was a threat to the tradition of male rule and Maat, D. Because she was a foreigner Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, the most similar generated MCQs are:

- Question 3: What was the significance of the pharaoh being known as the living embodiment of the male god Horus? (This question touches on the idea that the pharaoh being a woman was unusual, but it doesn't directly address why Hatshepsut becoming pharaoh was unusual.)
- Question 5: Why did Hatshepsut take the name Maatkare and sometimes refer to herself as Hatshepsu? (This question hints at the idea that Hatshepsut tried to adapt to the Egyptian belief in the link between order and patriarchy, which is related to why her becoming pharaoh was unusual.)
- Question 6: Who was the legitimate heir to the throne after Thutmose II's death? (This question addresses the issue of Hatshepsut not being the heir to the throne, which is part of why her becoming pharaoh was unusual.)

However, if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 6 is the most similar generated MCQ, as it directly addresses one of the reasons why Hatshepsut becoming pharaoh was unusual (she was not the legitimate heir to the throne).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Three and a half thousand years ago in Egypt, a noble pharaoh was the victim 
of a violent attack. But the attack was not physical. This royal had been dead for 20 years. The attack was historical, an act of damnatio memoriae,
the damnation of memory. Somebody smashed the pharaoh's statues, took a chisel and attempted to erase 
the pharaoh's name and image from history. Who was this pharaoh,
and what was behind the attack? Here's the key: the pharaoh Hatshepsut was a woman. In the normal course of things,
she should never have been pharaoh. Although it was legal 
for a woman to be a monarch, it disturbed some essential Egyptian beliefs. Firstly, the pharaoh was known
as the living embodiment of the male god Horus. Secondly, disturbance to the tradition
of rule by men was a serious challenge to Maat, a word for "truth," 
expressing a belief in order and justice, vital to the Egyptians. Hatshepsut had perhaps tried to adapt to this belief in the link between 
order and patriarchy through her titles. She took the name Maatkare, and sometimes referred to herself as Hatshepsu, 
with a masculine word ending. But apparently, these efforts 
didn't convince everyone, and perhaps someone 
erased Hatshepsut's image so that the world would forget 
the disturbance to Maat, and Egypt could be balanced again. Hatshepsut, moreover, 
was not the legitimate heir to the thrown, but a regent, 
a kind of stand-in co-monarch. The Egyptian kingship traditionally 
passed from father to son. It passed from Thutmose I 
to his son Thutmose II, Hatshepsut's husband. It should have passed from Thutmose II 
directly to his son Thutmose III, but Thutmose III was a little boy 
when his father died. Hatshepsut, the dead pharaoh's chief wife and widow, stepped in to help 
as her stepson's regent but ended up ruling beside him 
as a fully fledged pharaoh. Perhaps Thutmose III was angry about this. Perhaps he was the one 
who erased her images. It's also possible that someone wanted 
to dishonor Hatshepsut because she was a bad pharaoh. But the evidence suggests 
she was actually pretty good. She competently fulfilled 
the traditional roles of the office. She was a great builder. Her mortuary temple, Djeser-Djeseru, was an architectural phenomenon 
at the time and is still admired today. She enhanced the economy of Egypt, conducting a very successful trade mission
to the distant land of Punt. She had strong religious connections. She even claimed to be the daughter 
of the state god, Amun. And she had a successful military career,
with a Nubian campaign, and claims she fought alongside 
her soldiers in battle. Of course, we have to be careful
when we assess the success of Hatshepsut's career, since most of the evidence 
was written by Hatshepsut herself. She tells her own story 
in pictures and writing on the walls of her mortuary temple and the red chapel she built for Amun. So who committed the crimes 
against Hatshepsut's memory? The most popular suspect is 
her stepson, nephew and co-ruler, Thutmose III. Did he do it out of anger 
because she stole his throne? This is unlikely since 
the damage wasn't done until 20 years after Hatshepsut died. That's a long time to hang onto anger 
and then act in a rage. Maybe Thutmose III did it 
to make his own reign look stronger. But it is most likely that 
he or someone else erased the images so that people would forget 
that a woman ever sat on Egypt's throne. This gender anomaly was simply 
too much of a threat to Maat and had to be obliterated from history. Happily, the ancient censors 
were not quite thorough enough. Enough evidence survived for us 
to piece together what happened, so the story of this unique powerful woman
can now be told.
